chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of sleep apnoea
chapter.summary: Covers the primary care management of people with obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome (OSAS).
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 12 months onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer a person with suspected obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Refer urgently (2-week wait) to ear, nose, and throat (ENT) if there are features suggestive of a head and neck cancer. See the CKS topic on Head and neck cancers - recognition and referral for more information.
  • Refer to a sleep centre for confirmation of the diagnosis using sleep studies and for secondary care treatments (for example continuous positive airway pressure).
    • For adults, refer urgently those:
      • Who are sleepy whilst driving or working with machinery, or are employed in hazardous occupations (for example pilot or bus or lorry driver). Advise the person not to drive until they have been assessed by a specialist.
      • With signs of respiratory failure or heart failure.
      • With symptoms suggestive of severe obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome (OSAS) and coexistent chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
    • For adults, refer routinely those:
      • With symptoms suggestive of OSAS and/or an accompanying Epworth sleepiness questionnaire score of more than 10.
    • For adults where there are concerns about job security, ensure through personal communication with the sleep unit that diagnosis and treatment can be completed within four weeks of referral.
  • Refer children to:
    • A paediatric ENT specialist if they have clinical features of adenotonsillar hypertrophy, symptoms of persistent snoring, and features of OSAS.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Sleep studies
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Polysomnography (PSG) or a limited sleep study is used to measure apnoea/hypopnoea episodes and thereby confirm the diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome (OSAS) in adults and children.
    • PSG records sleep and breathing patterns simultaneously. It is routinely carried out in a sleep centre.
    • A limited sleep study is often used to diagnose OSAS and can be carried out in the person's home or in a sleep centre. Limited sleep studies record most of the parameters collected by PSG, with the exception of electroencephalography, which monitors sleep patterns.
  • The diagnosis of OSAS requires at least five episodes of apnoea, hypopnoea, or both events per hour of sleep.
  • The severity of OSAS is based on the number of apnoea/hypopnoea episodes per hour (apnoea-hypopnoea index [AHI]).
    • Mild: AHI 5–14 per hour.
    • Moderate: AHI 15–30 per hour.
    • Severe: AHI more than 30 per hour.

[SIGN, 2003; NICE, 2008; Powell et al, 2010]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Secondary care treatments
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Secondary care treatments for obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome (OSAS) include the use of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) or intra-oral devices.
    • CPAP is the first-line treatment for moderate or severe OSAS. CPAP should only be used in mild OSAS if a person has symptoms that affect quality of life (inability to carry out daily activities)andlifestyle advice or other treatments have failed or are inappropriate [NICE, 2008].
      • People will require lifelong treatment and have to wear either a nasal or face mask for airflow delivery at night.
      • Poor adherence to CPAP is common (because of a poorly fitting mask, problems with nasal dryness, nasal bleeding, or throat irritation).
      • Treatment with CPAP for OSAS has demonstrated significant reductions in both systolic and diastolic blood pressure [Montesi et al, 2012].
    • Intra-oral devices (such as a mandibular advancement device) are appropriate for people who snore or have mild OSAS with normal daytime alertness. Intra-oral devices can also be used as an alternative for people unable to tolerate CPAP [SIGN, 2003; Lim et al, 2006].
      • Sleep quality and nocturnal respiratory function are both improved following the use of a mandibular advancement device in people with OSAS. They are effective, non–invasive, and easy to manufacture [Lee et al, 2009].
  • Secondary care treatments for OSAS in children [Powell et al, 2010].
    • A child with clinical evidence of adenotonsillar hypertrophy may be offered adenotonsillectomy.
    • CPAP may need to be considered if adenotonsillectomy is contraindicated or not likely to be beneficial.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Urgent (2-week wait) ear, nose and throat (ENT) referral to exclude head and neck cancer
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Referral guidelines for suspected cancer [NICE, 2005] and the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) guideline Management of obstructive sleep apnoea/hypopnoea syndrome (OSAHS) in adults [SIGN, 2003].
Urgent referral of adults to a sleep centre
  • This recommendation is based on the SIGN guideline Management of obstructive sleep apnoea/hypopnoea syndrome (OSAHS) in adults [SIGN, 2003].
Routine referral of adults to a sleep centre
  • This recommendation is largely based on the SIGN guideline Management of obstructive sleep apnoea/hypopnoea syndrome (OSAHS) in adults [SIGN, 2003] and the NICE guideline Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) for the treatment of sleep apnoea/hypopnoea syndrome [NICE, 2008].
    • After the diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome (OSAS) is confirmed, referrals within the sleep centre may be made (for example ENT advice for people with enlarged tonsils or a deviated nasal septum, or referral to an orthodontist for construction of an intra-oral device).
Concerns about job security
  • This recommendation is based on the Four-Week Wait Campaign - For the treatment of obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome (OSAS) [OSA Partnership Group, 2015].
    • The treatment of vocational drivers with obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome (OSAS) should be expedited to allow driving again within a maximum of four weeks following first referral.
Referral of children to ENT
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in a clinical review article published in the British Medical Journal (BMJ), Paediatric obstructive sleep apnoea [Powell et al, 2010]. Children with clinical evidence of adenotonsillar hypertrophy and symptoms of persistent snoring plus any features of obstructive sleep apnoea require referral to a paediatric ENT specialist.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with confirmed obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If appropriate, give lifestyle advice on:
    • Weight loss, exercise, reducing alcohol intake and sedative use, and smoking cessation — see the CKS topics on Obesity, Alcohol - problem drinking, and Smoking cessation for more information.
    • Sleeping position — if the person sleeps supine, advise them to try sleeping on their side.
  • Assess the person's risk of cardiovascular disease and diabetes. See the CKS topics on CVD risk assessment and management and Diabetes - type 2 for more information.
  • Monitor the person's blood pressure regularly.
  • Encourage adherence to treatment, such as continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) or intra-oral devices. Explain that both CPAP and intra-oral devices help manage symptoms and reduce the risk of long–term complications.
  • Give advice on driving and entitlement to drive. Advise the person to check with their insurer that they are still insured to drive under their current policy.
  • Give information on support groups that provide self-management advice, for example The Sleep Apnoea Trust Association (www.sleep-apnoea-trust.org), which has an information leaflet on obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) guideline Management of obstructive sleep apnoea/hypopnoea syndrome (OSAHS) in adults [SIGN, 2003].

Advice on weight loss and exercise
  • Expert opinion in a clinical review article from the British Medical Journal, Obstructive sleep apnoea, concluded that weight reduction programmes are not to be thought of as curative but rather as adjunctive for people with obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome (OSAS) [Greenstone and Hack, 2014].
  • A meta-analysis of 5 small studies (n = 129) found a reduction in the apnoea/hypopnoea index (AHI) by –6.27 events/hour following supervised exercise training. This demonstrated a reduction in the severity of sleep apnoea (with minimal changes in body weight) with exercise [Iftikhar et al, 2014].
Alcohol, smoking, and sleeping supine
  • The recommendations regarding alcohol use and smoking cessation are largely based on expert opinion in a review article The epidemiology of adult obstructive sleep apnoeapublished in the American Thoracic Society Journal [Punjabi, 2008].
    • Alcohol before sleep has been shown to increase the likelihood of airway collapse and precipitate apnoea and hypopnoea during sleep.
    • Smoking is thought to be associated with a higher prevalence of snoring and OSAS. It is suggested that airway inflammation and damage due to cigarette smoke could alter the mechanical and neural properties of the upper airways and increase airway collapse during sleep.
  • A review article in The Journal of Family Practice, How should we diagnose and treat obstructive sleep apnoea? recommends lateral sleep positioning [Holten, 2004]. The authors of a review article in the European Respiratory Journal, Recommendations for the management of patients with obstructive sleep apnoea and hypertension, recommend to avoid sleeping in the supine position as polysomnographic recordings demonstrate apnoeic events occur in such a posture [Parati et al, 2013].
Assessing for risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and diabetes
  • A systematic review of 6 studies (n = 8785) found that OSAS was nonsignificantly associated with ischaemic heart disease. The authors propose that OSAS may independently increase cardiovascular risk, however there were confounding cardiovascular risk factors already present in the study population which may reduce the strength of this association. It concludes that more studies are required to identify if good management of OSAS reduces cardiovascular events [Loke et al, 2012].
  • A meta-analysis of six prospective cohort studies (n = 5953) found that moderate to severe OSAS is associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes. The results also indicated that OSAS may be an independent risk factor for the development of type 2 diabetes [Wang et al, 2013].
Monitoring blood pressure
  • The recommendation on monitoring blood pressure is based on a review article in the European Respiratory Journal, Recommendations for the management of patients with obstructive sleep apnoea and hypertension [Parati et al, 2013].
Encouraging compliance with treatment
  • This recommendation is based on the SIGN guideline Management of obstructive sleep apnoea/hypopnoea syndrome (OSAHS) in adults [SIGN, 2003].
Advice on driving
  • This recommendation is based on information from the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) guidance for medical practitioners, At a glance guide to the current medical standards of fitness to drive [DVLA, 2014], and the British Thoracic Society position statement Driving and Obstructive Sleep Apnoea (OSA)/Obstructive Sleep Apnoea Syndrome (OSAS) [British Thoracic Society, 2014].
Information on support groups
  • This recommendation is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What advice should I give about driving?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The British Thoracic Society (BTS) gives the following advice regarding driving for people with obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome (OSAS):
    • The person does not need to stop driving, or inform the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) if:
      • They are being investigated for, or have a diagnosis of, sleep apnoea, but do not experience symptoms of daytime sleepiness that are of a severity likely to impair driving.
    • The person should inform the DVLA (but not cease driving) if:
      • They are successfully using continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) or an intra-oral device. As long as the person is compliant with treatment and their symptoms are controlled such that they no longer impair driving, their licence should not be affected.
    • The person has a legal requirement to inform the DVLA and stop driving if:
      • They are diagnosed with OSAS, and the symptoms include sufficient sleepiness to impair driving.
      • Prior to formal diagnosis, the person is reporting sufficient levels of sleepiness to impair driving, and there is a reasonable chance that this is due to a medical condition.
    • This guidance is applicable to both Group 1 (cars, mopeds, and motorbikes) and Group 2 (lorries and buses) drivers. In addition, for Group 2 drivers, compliance with treatment and ongoing symptom control must be assessed on a regular, usually annual basis, by the sleep specialist.
  • Detailed information is available on the BTS website (www.brit-thoracic.org.uk) and information from the DVLA regarding medical fitness to drive can be found at www.gov.uk/government/publications/at-a-glance.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: • The information on driving regulations is taken from the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) guidance for medical practitioners, At a glance guide to the current medical standards of fitness to drive [DVLA, 2014], and the British Thoracic Society position statement Driving and Obstructive Sleep Apnoea (OSA)/Obstructive Sleep Apnoea Syndrome (OSAS) [British Thoracic Society, 2014].
